fullText:
LOS ANGELES â€” In just nine days, teams across MLB will begin to have their pitchers and catchers report to Spring Training, and one familiar superstar has already begun his preparation ahead of the chaos.

Coming off back-to-back World Series titles with the Los Angeles Dodgers, Shohei Ohtani begins year three in Dodger blue with a head start, as he was seen Wednesday morning working on his pitching mechanics at the Dodgers Spring Training Facility in Glendale, Arizona.

Itâ€™s widely known that, when it comes to perfecting the little details in terms of a routine, Ohtani is the most precise in the league, and he displayed it once more, going through every second of his pitching motion.

Even down to his foot pushing off the rubber, every movement has to flow to perfection.

The world saw the likes of Ohtani pitching for the Dodgers for the first time last year as the season began to wind down, and it was also the first time we got to see the two-way unicorn step on the mound in the postseason en route to the Dodgers' third World Series title in the last five years.

Ohtani went through a tedious, yet instrumental, comeback in terms of rehab when it came to his pitching.

Whether it was through a precarious number of live bullpen sessions sprinkled in throughout the majority of the 2025 season, or frequent throwing assignments hours before games, every pitch was a telltale sign of Ohtaniâ€™s pitching dominance beginning to shine through.

Now, after scratching off pitching in the postseason for the first time and essentially full steam ahead to pitch with no restrictions in 2026, Ohtani will look forward to next season as the year he contributes on the pitching side for Los Angeles.

Ohtani was thought to be working even earlier on his pitching, as he said at DodgersFest last Saturday that there was a possibility that he would pitch for Team Japan in the WBC.

Dodgers manager Dave Roberts quickly shot down the idea of Ohtani stepping on the mound for Team Japan a little over an hour after Ohtani spoke to the media, and it was revealed on Tuesday that insurance would not be written off on Ohtani as a pitcher anyway.

With the WBC out of mind, Ohtaniâ€™s early ramp up to Spring Training rewrites the narrative once more that, not only does he want to be a factor to the Dodgers starting rotation in 2026, which is headlined by the likes of fellow countrymen Yoshinobu Yamamoto and Roki Sasaki, along with Tyler Glasnow and Blake Snell, but add another piece of hardware to an undeniable resume.

The 31-year-old Japanese superstar is a four-time unanimous MVP winner, five-time All-Star, four-time Silver Slugger, three-time Hank Aaron Award winner, and American League Rookie of the Year winner in 2018, but the coveted Cy Young Award is the only piece missing from his trophy cabinet.

If everything goes according to plan and Ohtani can stray away from injury to his throwing arm, 2026 will be the first season Ohtani pitches for Los Angeles from the jump and could notch 20-plus starts like years past.

title: ESPN insider: Kevin McGonigle will make 'immediate impact' for Tigers
description: ESPN MLB reporter Buster Olney predicts that Detroit Tigers top prospect Kevin McGonigle will make an "immediate impact" in 2026.
fullText:
The Detroit Tigers have a couple top prospects who could see big league action very soon, with one in particular getting MLB experts excited.

ESPN's MLB analysts provided predictions for various top prospects in an article published on Tuesday, Feb. 3, and Buster Olney kicked it off with Tigers infielder Kevin McGonigle, currently ranked as the No. 2 prospect in baseball by ESPN.

"No matter where he plays, McGonigle will be a fixture in the Tigers' every-day lineup by midseason and make an immediate impact," he wrote.

The "immediate impact" part of his analysis may not surprise Tigers fans, or at least those who read prospect lists. McGonigle is the top prospect in the Tigers' system and a near-consensus top-2 prospect in baseball, with MLB Pipeline and Baseball America (like ESPN) ranking him No. 2 overall below Pittsburgh Pirates shortstop Konnor Griffin.

McGonigle also slashed .254/.369/.550 in 206 plate appearances across 46 games at Double-A Erie in 2025, showing off professional-level hitting skills that could fit in immediately with the Tigers lineup. And with some exposure at third base in the 2025 Arizona Fall League season (where he continued to hit exceptionally well), he could also bring some defensive versatility to the Tigers.

HOW TO WATCH: Detroit Tigers leaving FanDuel Sports Network for MLB Media: Report

What Tigers fans might be more interested in, however, is Olney predicting McGonigle will be in the Tigers lineup by midseason.

If the Tigers were to wait until around mid-May to call up McGonigle, they would retain an extra year of service time for their top prospect, meaning McGonigle would be in line to become a free agent in 2032 instead of 2031. That extra year for a prospect as highly praised as McGonigle could be incredibly valuable for the Tigers, meaning he might start the season in the minors instead of in Detroit.

However, there are also strong arguments for calling up McGonigle to start the season. The Tigers have not signed a dedicated third baseman to their roster for 2026, right now projecting to use Colt Keith and Zach McKinstry at the position. McGonigle could potentially fill that role (while also able to play second base and shortstop) and bring a spark to the lineup.

The Tigers could also benefit from MLB's Prospect Promotion Incentive if they call up McGonigle within the first two weeks of the season, potentially earning an extra draft pick should McGonigle finish in the top-3 in the American League Rookie of the Year vote in 2026.

Tigers president of baseball operations Scott Harris addressed the team's plans for McGonigle at his end-of-season press conference in October (without naming McGonigle specifically), saying: "I expect the players that posted dominant years in Double-A to factor into our big-league team next year ... I expect them to be in Detroit at some point next year."

The move that might make the most sense for the Tigers is to call up McGonigle in the middle of the season to take advantage of his production while retaining an extra year of his eligibility. If the Tigers were to call up McGonigle in late May or early June, for example, they could get McGonigle in the lineup for a huge chunk of their season without starting his service clock â€“â  though they wouldn't be eligible for a PPI pick.

But either way, it shouldn't surprise Tigers fans if McGonigle is up at some point in the 2026 season.

You can reach Christian at cromo@freepress.com.

title: Yankees get lackluster offseason grade amid shaky reliance on five players
description: These five players are being relied upon too much for this ex-MLB GM.
fullText:
Yankees get lackluster offseason grade amid shaky reliance on five players originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The New York Yankees didn't have the most prolific offseason. They didn't land multiple All-Stars like the New York Mets or the Los Angeles Dodgers, and didn't swing big deals and trades like the Toronto Blue Jays, Baltimore Orioles, or Boston Red Sox.

But the Yankees did bring back Trent Grisham and Cody Bellinger, along with trading for Ryan Weathers to go with the plethora of depth additions Brian Cashman made.

While the 94-68 Yankees are running it back, Jim Bowden of The Athletic gave the Yankees a "C" grade for their offseason. He highlighted five players the Yankees are relying on, and expressed concern about whether they should rely on those players or not.

"The Yankees will be counting on Gerrit Cole, Carlos Rodon, and Anthony Volpe to successfully return from their injuries after starting the season on the IL," Bowden writes. "They are hopeful Volpe, Austin Wells, and Ben Rice will have breakout seasons."

Thanks to very few changes being made to the roster for the 2026 season, the Yankees will need to get a lot of development and progress from these five players.

Bowden singled out Cole and Rodon as two of the Yankees' biggest question marks for the 2026 season: "Can Cole and Rodon bounce back from their injuries to give the Yankees one of the best starting rotations in baseball?"

While seeing Cole and Rodon bounce back in a major way is within the realm of possibility, there's no guarantee when they'll be back, and even when they do return, they might not be nearly as good as they once were.

More:Â Yankees reveal plans for power prospect Spencer Jones

Relying on Rodon and Cole for a positive outlook in 2026 is risky for the Yankees, and that's not the only risk at play.

When Volpe returns from injury is also uncertain, and as Bowden notes, the Yankees will not just need him back; they will be hoping for a breakout year from the young shortstop.

Relying on Volpe to such a degree is a lot on his plate, and even though Aaron Judge, Bellinger, and others will help alleviate the need for Volpe to breakout to win, to get over the hump and back into the World Series, he likely does need to breakout.

Add on that the Yankees are relying on Wells and Rice to both break out, and this upcoming season is a very risky one for the Yankees.

Relying on multiple, if not all of these players, to breakout in 2026 is a very shaky path for the Yankees. It's possible, but not the most likely outcome. If it doesn't happen, 2026 could be a disappointing season.

title: 2026 MLB MVP Odds: Ohtani Continues Chasing History
description: MLB MVP betting favorites for 2026. Shohei Ohtani is favored in the NL, and Aaron Judge is on top in the AL.
fullText:
At -125, Shohei Ohtani is breathing rarefied air at his current price.

Consider last year, when he was the overwhelming preseason favorite to win NL MVP, and he was still only +150 by the end of March, per Sports Odds History. That was already crazy, because the shortest number we've generally seen in recent years is +200 or +300.

Below, we'll look at the early MLB odds for the 2026 season, and AL & NL MVP, as the likes of Alex Bregman (Chicago Cubs) and Kyle Tucker (Los Angeles Dodgers) have found new homes since our previous look.

Here are the last 10 winners of the AL and NL MVP Award, with Shohei Ohtani leading the way as a four-time winner, with two in the AL and two in the NL. Only Frank Robinson has also won MVP awards in both leagues.

Barry Bonds holds the record for most MVP awards (seven)

The New York Yankees have won the most MVPs in MLB history with 25, while the St. Louis Cardinals are second, leading all NL teams, with 21. No player for the Arizona Diamondbacks, New York Mets, or Tampa Bay Rays has ever won MVP.

Most sportsbooks will display odds in the American format as listed above. When Goldschmidt ran away with the MVP award in 2022 his odds had a minus (-) sign ahead of the number for a large part of the season.

That means that a bettor in August had to wager $6,000 to win $100 by betting on Goldy to win MVP. Before the season starts, almost every player will have a plus (+) sign ahead of their odds.

That means a bettor would have profited $200 for a $100 wager on Ohtani before the season started.

If American odds aren't your thing, simply use a tool like our odds converter to switch the odds to decimal or fractional format. Most online sportsbooks also give you the option to change the odds format that you see.

title: Inside the Dodgers TV Deal That Helped Launch a Dynasty
description: Amid the talk about the Dodgers' spending, a special agreement between MLB and the Dodgers over L.A.'s TV money share has come up.
fullText:
Amid the conversation about the teamâ€™s spending, the Los Angeles Dodgersâ€™ TV deal with Spectrum has come up, namely, a special clause that allows the Dodgers to retain an additional portion of their TV revenue.

The signing of outfielder Kyle Tucker has sparked a total meltdown on social media, with fanbases from all over the MLB spectrum coming out of the woodwork and calling out the Dodgers for â€œruining baseball.â€

Tucker is set to earn $60 million per season, an incredibly high average annual value, which will have him among the highest-paid athletes in the sport. He is joining a team already full of stars in Mookie Betts, Shohei Ohtani, and Freddie Freeman â€” the reigning World Series champions.

As a result, an agreement between the Dodgersâ€™ owners, the Guggenheim Group, and MLB has begun to circulate.

The LA Timesâ€™ Bill Shaikin outlined the terms of the deal between MLB and the Dodgers that have indeed led to the team keeping a larger share of its revenue.

While trying to oust Frank McCourt as an owner in MLB, the league blocked a $3 billion deal between the Dodgers and Fox Sports, prompting McCourt to file a suit in bankruptcy court.

McCourt was trying to sell the team for all its worth, and he needed to make sure bidders knew what to expect from a TV deal.

In bankruptcy court, MLB agreed that the fair-market value for the Dodgersâ€™ TV deal was the Fox offer, meaning the league would take its 34 percent cut based on those terms.

However, the Dodgers ended up striking a deal worth more than $8 billion, though MLB could not take more from the new deal.

During an appearance on Dodgers Dougout with Doug McKain, Shakin explained how the deal materialized.

â€œIn a nutshell, in order to get Frank McCourt out, which was the objective from MLB, they had to make a deal with him in bankruptcy court,â€ Shakin said on the show.

â€œAnd part of that deal was how are you going to value the television contract? And since a television contract did not exist at that time, because a new owner had not even been selected, they did the best they could.

â€œAnd Guggenheim came out with a really great offer that I think blew even MLBâ€™s wildest expectations away. MLB wasnâ€™t thrilled, but theyâ€™re living by the terms of the deal, and thatâ€™s where we are.â€

A lot of people have been on the timeline complaining about the Dodgers â€œunfair TV dealâ€

The truth is even if the Dodgers gave up more of that money to other teams, opposing owners still wouldnâ€™t spend ????

(W/ @dmac_la) pic.twitter.com/f4wkjmBU4D

â€” Dodgers Nation (@DodgersNation) January 28, 2026

MLB did try to push for new terms that hold the Dodgers to the same standard as other teams, but the settlement in bankruptcy court was too much of a blocker.

However, as Shakin outlines, the Dodgersâ€™ new owners, Guggenheim, did work with MLB to find a middle ground.

â€œSo in a normal situation, Major League Baseball would have said, this is a crazy high deal and good for you, and weâ€™re happy, but we gotta share this money just like we share any other money.

â€œAnd in this case, MLB could only push so far because Guggenheim was willing to work with MLB to a point. And then Guggenheim could have gone back to the court and said, â€˜we got a deal, please, Mr. Judge, enforce the deal. Thatâ€™s what youâ€™re here for.â€™

â€œAnd the court, as they say in legal circles, has jurisdiction over the deal, which means they run everything.

â€œSo, MLB could have been stuck with the original settlement, which was not as favorable as what they got in the negotiations with Guggenheim.

â€œIs it equal for all other teams? Absolutely not. Is it a competitive advantage for the Dodgers? Sure. Now, is it as big a competitive advantage as some people are making it? I donâ€™t think so â€™cause the contract itself is way more than the individual amount the Dodgers are saving every year.â€

title: MLB Trade Rumors: DET Tigersâ€™ Asking Price for Tarik Skubal Pushed 2 Teams Out
description: Detroit Tigers starting pitcher Tarik Skubal is the best pitcher in baseball and is currently pushing for one of the [â€¦]
fullText:
Detroit Tigers starting pitcher Tarik Skubal is the best pitcher in baseball and is currently pushing for one of the largest arbitration salaries in MLB history. He has also been the subject of MLB trade rumors, but Detroitâ€™s demands could prevent a deal from happening.

Appearing in a Bleacher Report live stream, MLB insider Jon Heyman of the New York Post said that while the Tigers havenâ€™t exactly named a clear price for Skubal that theyâ€™ve set their demands high enough that it pushed two teams out of the hunt.

â€œIt is highâ€¦My impression from the Yankees and the Mets is that it was too high for themâ€¦Detroit isnâ€™t exactly naming the exact prices, so itâ€™s not really a two-way discussion at this points. Teams are making offers and I donâ€™t think they are coming close at this point.â€

Jon Heyman on the Detroit Tigers asking price for a Tarik Skubal trade

Heyman noted that while the Yankees are interested in adding another starting pitcher, there is zero interest in meeting the demands set by Detroit. New York is adamant about not including starting pitcher Cam Schlittler, top prospect George Lombard Jr., and potentially even more for the two-time AL Cy Young Award winner.

As for the Mets, they already made their aggressive move to fortify the starting rotation with the trade for All-Star pitcher Freddy Peralta. New York also acquired Tobias Myers in the deal, and after dealing several of its top prospects, the club does not want to give up even more for a one-season rental of Skubal.

The Tigersâ€™ extremely high asking price for Skubal certainly isnâ€™t surprising. He has recorded the lowest ERA in the American League in each of the past two seasons and sports a 2.39 ERA with a 0.90 WHIP and a 38â€“13 record across 467.2 innings over the last three seasons. He is without question the best starter in baseball.

Entering a contract year, however, teams simply are not willing to gut their farm systems and move several of their top prospects for an ace who will test the open market next winter. Realistically, Skubal will be Detroitâ€™s Opening Day starter, and a trade is likelier to happen before the MLB trade deadline on August 3.

title: MLB: Top 10 Shortstops heading into the 2026 season
description: Ranking shortstops is never just about comparing stat lines. It is about identifying who provides the most value in baseballâ€™s most demanding position. MLB Networkâ€™s â€œThe Shredderâ€ combines recent performance with a deep dive into offensive and defensive metrics toâ€¦
fullText:
Ranking shortstops is never just about comparing stat lines. It is about identifying who provides the most value in baseballâ€™s most demanding position. MLB Networkâ€™s â€œThe Shredderâ€ combines recent performance with a deep dive into offensive and defensive metrics to sort the elite from the very good. Here are the 10 players it rates highest as we approach the 2026 campaign.

Stats to know:Â 26 HR, 26 SB (2025).

Neto lands at number 10 on both The Shredderâ€™s list and Brian Kennyâ€™s personal rankings, which speaks volumes about his rapid ascent. The logic for his inclusion is simple enough. He is already producing power and speed from a premium spot on the diamond very early in his career. For the Angels, that dual-threat ability is the cornerstone of a lineup that desperately needs reliable production up the middle.â€‹

De La Cruz checks in at number nine on The Shredderâ€™s 2026 list, a clear nod to a toolkit that can alter the course of a game even when he isnâ€™t fully dialed in. He holds the same spot on MLB.comâ€™s recap, keeping him firmly within the positionâ€™s top tier. His appeal is easy to see. He pressures defenses in ways that almost no other shortstop can, forcing the league to account for him on every single pitch.â€‹

Stats to know:Â .840 OPS (2025).

PeÃ±a arrives at number eight for 2026, marking his first appearance in the Top 10 at shortstop according to MLB.com. This detail is significant because these lists typically favor sustained value over isolated hot streaks. Houston has always asked its shortstops to be steady with the glove and productive at the plate, and PeÃ±aâ€™s recent performance confirms he is meeting that high standard.

Turner sits at number seven on the SI-reported Shredder list, occupying the territory where consistency and track record start to weigh as heavily as peak potential. His ranking reflects an established history of production that keeps him relevant even as the position gets younger and deeper. When a player remains in this tier year after year, it signals that analysts still trust his baseline contributions despite a crowded field at the top.â€‹

Stats to know:Â 20 HR, 7.1 FanGraphs WAR (2025).

Perdomo lands in sixth place, a jump framed by MLB.com as the result of a breakout season that redefined his profile. While the power surge grabbed headlines, the real differentiator at shortstop is when that offense comes without sacrificing defense. For Arizona, this ranking serves as validation that his strong season wasnâ€™t a fluke. It has moved him onto the short list of the gameâ€™s best at his position.

Stats to know:Â 21 Outs Above Average (led NL SS), 17 Defensive Runs Saved (most among SS).â€‹

Betts holds the fifth spot for a second consecutive year, which is impressive considering he is still relatively new to playing shortstop full-time. The defensive metrics highlighted in the SI report explain why he remains here. The model is rewarding legitimate shortstop value rather than just a superstar playing out of position. With the Dodgers committing to him as their starter for 2026, this isnâ€™t a temporary experiment. It is simply their plan.â€‹

Henderson ranks fourth on the 2026 list after entering last season at number one. This placement matters because it suggests his overall package remains elite even if the top spot has shifted. In a ranking system that weighs both offense and defense, staying in the top four means you are impacting the game on both sides of the ball rather than just compiling counting stats.â€‹

Lindor slots in at number three, a ranking reserved for players who deliver reliable output year after year at a position that exposes every flaw. He also takes third on MLB.comâ€™s recap, reinforcing that his standing is one of the least debated in the top 10. When a position is this deep, being a consensus top-three choice is an accomplishment in itself. It means your floor is respected just as much as your ceiling.â€‹

Seager enters 2026 at number two on The Shredderâ€™s list, keeping him squarely in the conversation for the gameâ€™s best shortstop. He also holds the second spot on MLB.comâ€™s published rankings, aligning the broader view with the modelâ€™s data. The main takeaway here is stability. Even with constant turnover around the league, the rankings continue to treat him as a pillar near the very top of the position.â€‹

Stats to know:Â Led MLB in hits for the second straight season.

Witt claims the number one spot for 2026, becoming the sixth different shortstop to lead the list in the last six years. MLB.com links his rise directly to his production, specifically highlighting his back-to-back seasons leading the majors in hits. In a model built to blend offense, defense, and overall impact, that combination of volume and value is exactly what pushes a player to the top of the list.â€‹

Rankings donâ€™t win games, but they do show where the leagueâ€™s most dependable two-way value can be found. This top 10 reminds us that playing shortstop in 2026 requires a wide range of skills that all lead to the same result: winning impact. The only real verdict will come in April when these names have to turn their list positions into victories on the field.

title: MLB analyst discuss where Eugenio Suarez should play next season
description: As the third-base slugger remains on the free agent market, this former MLB player discusses his best fit for the 2026 season.
fullText:
MLB analyst discuss where Eugenio Suarez should play next season originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

This MLB offseason has been one to remember, with many big-time players deciding to join other teams, such as Pete Alonso, Kyle Tucker, and Alex Bregman, and others choosing to remain with their teams from last season, like Kyle Schwarber and Cody Bellinger.

With spring training coming around sooner rather than later, most of the notable players have been signed and off the market, but there are still a few big names out there.

More:Â How Jose Ramirez is on pace to become Cleveland's Derek Jeter

Eugenio Suarez, who spent last season with the Seattle Mariners after being traded from the Arizona Diamondbacks and nearly helped lead the team to the World Series before losing to the Toronto Blue Jays in seven games in the ALDS, is still available.

Suarez is a big bat that can be useful for many teams, considering the slugger ranked in the top five in the league in RBIs with 118 and home runs with 49 to complement a .228 batting average, and when discussing where the third basemen's next move, Mike Lowell heavily advocated for a full season with the Mariners for the 34-year-old.

"I think the most logical landing spot for Eugenio is back in Seattle," Lowell stated.

Lowell explained himself, stating that the Mariners are more aware of his ups and downs: he can be extremely hot at times, capable of putting a team on his back, but also extremely cold when he struggles.

The two-time World Series champion also described Suarez as one of the most durable third basemen in the league, while giving a team 40-50 home runs a year, which makes him an excellent fit for any team.

description: Judge is front and center ahead of the World Baseball Classic.
fullText:
Yankees' Aaron Judge featured on cover of MLB The Show 26 originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

New York Yankees star Aaron Judge was revealed as the cover athlete for this year's edition of MLB The Show.

Judge joins former Minnesota Twins Hall of Fame catcher Joe Mauer as just the second player to appear on the game's cover twice (2010 and 2011). After a standout rookie season in 2017, Judge was the cover athlete for MLB The Show 18.

The Yankees captain has won back-to-back AL MVPs and is already one of the greatest right-handed hitters in Major League history. MLB The Show 26 will release on March 17.

"I play a lot of video games, so it was always a dream of mine to somehow still be involved and have some type of impact," Judge told ESPN. "So then when they called and said, 'Hey, we want to have you on there again,' it was pretty surreal."

Manager Mark DeRosa named Judge the captain of Team USA for this year's World Baseball Classic. This will be the 33-year-old's first time participating in the tournament.

Joining Judge on the United States roster will be more than a dozen MLB All-Stars and former Cy Young Award and MVP winners. Tarik Skubal, Paul Skenes, and Bryce Harper are just a few of the names slated to take the field in March.

Judge is entering his 11th season with the Yankees. He has hit 52 or more home runs four times in his career, and led all qualified hitters with a 1.144 OPS and 215 OPS+ in 2025.

title: MLB: Ranking the top 10 richest free agent signings of 2026 offseason
description: The hot stove is officially burning. While pitchers and catchers donâ€™t report until mid-February, the 2026 offseason has already delivered a flurry of massive contracts, trades, and extensions. From record-breaking re-signings to blockbuster moves for new faces, teams are openingâ€¦
fullText:
The hot stove is officially burning. While pitchers and catchers donâ€™t report until mid-February, the 2026 offseason has already delivered a flurry of massive contracts, trades, and extensions. From record-breaking re-signings to blockbuster moves for new faces, teams are opening their checkbooks to secure the talent needed for a World Series run. Here are the top 10 richest deals signed so far this winter, ranked by total contract value.

Deal:Â 2 years, $40 million
The Mets continue to spend aggressively, bolstering their infield with Polanco. At $20 million per year, itâ€™s a significant commitment for a veteran bat who brings switch-hitting power and versatility. This move signals New Yorkâ€™s intent to add reliable offensive depth to its star-studded lineup.

Deal:Â 3 years, $45 million
Philadelphia locks up its field general, ensuring continuity behind the plate. While the annual value is lower than his previous market-setting deal, this contract keeps one of the gameâ€™s best all-around catchers in red pinstripes. Itâ€™s a move about stability and leadership for a team with championship aspirations.

The Braves invest heavily in their bullpen, signing Suarez to lock down the late innings. After saving 40 games with a sub-3.00 ERA, he commands a premium price for a reliever. This deal reflects the modern emphasis on elite bullpen arms as essential postseason weapons.

Deal:Â 5 years, $57.5 million (Extension)
Kansas City bets on its young core, extending its third baseman through his prime years. Garciaâ€™s breakout 2025 season, featuring 16 homers and 23 steals, secured his financial future and solidified his status as a cornerstone player. The Blue Jays tap into the international market, bringing Japanese slugger Okamoto to North America. With a track record of elite power in the NPB, including a record-breaking 56-homer season, he offers high-upside offensive potential. This signing is a calculated risk to inject power into the middle of Torontoâ€™s order.

Deal:Â 3 years, $126 million
In a stunning splash, the Mets land the All-Star shortstop on a massive short-term deal. The high AAV ($42 million) allows Bichette to re-enter the market while giving New York an elite bat in his prime. Itâ€™s a â€œwin-nowâ€ move that reshapes their infield and adds another premium playmaker to the mix.

Deal:Â 5 years, $130 million
Boston addresses its most significant need, starting pitching, by poaching a reliable arm from a rival. Suarez brings playoff experience and a lefty profile that should play well at Fenway Park. This contract signifies that the Red Sox are done sitting on the sidelines and are ready to spend for rotation stability.

Deal:Â 5 years, $150 million (Extension)
The Phillies ensure their designated slugger isnâ€™t going anywhere. Schwarberâ€™s ability to hit homers in bunches and work walks makes him a unique offensive force. This deal keeps the heart of Philadelphiaâ€™s order intact, prioritizing power and clubhouse leadership for the foreseeable future.

Deal:Â 5 years, $155 million
In perhaps the offseasonâ€™s biggest shocker, the Orioles swipe the â€œPolar Bearâ€ from their division rivals. Alonsoâ€™s prodigious power (38 homers, 126 RBIs) immediately transforms Baltimoreâ€™s lineup into a juggernaut. Itâ€™s a statement signing that declares the Orioles are ready to dominate the AL East for years to come.

Deal:Â 5 years, $162.5 million (Extension)
The Yankees retain their star outfielder with the richest deal of the winter so far. Bellingerâ€™s bounce-back performance proved heâ€™s still an elite contributor, and New York paid a premium to keep his left-handed bat in the Bronx. This contract solidifies the Yankeesâ€™ outfield and keeps a key piece of their championship puzzle in place.

With Jose Ramirezâ€™s reworked $175 million deal also making headlines, the market is clearly robust for elite talent. As spring training approaches, expect a few more dominoes to fall, but for now, these 10 deals define the financial landscape of the 2026 season.

title: Chicago Cubs history unpacked, January 26
description: A Chicago Cubs-centric digest, with #Cubs, #MLB, and #MiLB content.
fullText:
On Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays,Â Bleed Cubbie BlueÂ is pleased to present aÂ Cubs-centric look at baseballâ€™s colorful past.Â Hereâ€™s a handy Cubs timeline, to help you follow the various narrative paths.

â€œMaybe I called it wrong, but itâ€™s official.â€ â€”Â Tom Connolly, HoF Umpire.

Steve Trout* and others are traded for, plus the expanded strike zone and more! Where were you when it really snowed in Chicago?

1931 â€“Â TheÂ International LeagueÂ accepts theÂ open draftÂ imposed by the major leagues. Until this time, the top minor leagues could control their players and refuse to sell them. (2)

1932Â â€“Â Chicago CubsÂ ownerÂ William WrigleyÂ dies at the age of 70 inÂ Phoenix, Arizona. Wrigley had owned the team sinceÂ 1919. Wrigleyâ€™s sonÂ PhilipÂ inherits controlling interest in both theÂ CubsÂ and theÂ minor leagueÂ Los Angeles AngelsÂ of theÂ Pacific Coast League, but will leave most of the daily operations to Cubs presidentÂ William Veeck. (1,2)

1963Â â€“Â Major League Baseballâ€™sÂ RulesÂ Committee increases the size of theÂ strike zone. The zone will stretch from the top of the batterâ€™s shoulders to the bottom of the knees. The committee hopes the return to theÂ 1950sÂ strike zone will result in a decrease in runs scored. The results will exceed the committeeâ€™s expectations, and after the â€œYear of the Pitcherâ€ inÂ 1968, the strike zone will be tweaked again to give the hitters a break. (2)

1983Â â€“ TheÂ Chicago White SoxÂ trade pitchersÂ Steve Trout* andÂ Warren BrusstarÂ to their cross-town rivalsÂ CubsÂ for pitchersÂ Dick TidrowÂ andÂ Randy Martz, and infieldersÂ Pat TablerÂ andÂ Scott Fletcher. (2)

1989Â â€“ The tougherÂ balkÂ rules initiated last season are rescinded and are replaced by the pre-1988 rules. (2)

Cubs Birthdays: Rip Russell,Â Kevin Blankenship.

1531Â â€“ Lisbon hit by Earthquake; about 30,000 die.

1784Â â€“ Benjamin Franklin expresses unhappiness over eagle as Americaâ€™s symbol.

1788Â â€“ Captain Arthur Phillip and British colonists hoist the Union Flag at Sydney Cove, New South Wales, now celebrated as Australia Day. Referred to as Invasion Day by some First Nations people.

1887Â â€“ Ground is broken and construction begins on the Eiffel Tower in Paris, France.

1967Â â€“ Chicago â€œBig Snowâ€ strikes with a record 23 inches of snow fall causing 800 buses and 50,000 automobiles to be abandoned.

(1) â€”Â Today in Baseball History.

(3) â€”Â Society for American Baseball Research.

(5) â€”Â This Day in Chicago Cubs history.

Some of these items spread from site to site without being fact-checked, and that is why we ask for verifiable sources, in order to help correct the record.

title: MLB Insider Predicts Outcome for Tarik Skubal Arbitration Case With Detroit Tigers
description: ESPNâ€™s Jeff Passan explains why Tarik Skubal could win a record $32 million in arbitration over the Tigersâ€™ $19M offer, citing Cy Young history and elite performance.
fullText:
The Detroit Tigers and Tarik Skubal are staring at a number that has never existed in an arbitration hearing before.

Skubalâ€™s side filed at $32 million for the 2026 season. The Tigers countered at $19 million. That $13 million spread is not just large, itâ€™s unprecedented. No arbitration case in MLB history has featured anything close to that kind of gap, and no player has ever been awarded a salary anywhere near $32 million through the process.

Yet, according to ESPNâ€™s Jeff Passan, history may be about to bend.

Passanâ€™s argument centers on one simple truth: Skubal isnâ€™t just elite, heâ€™s in rare, historic territory.

â€œEven if the comparables are in Detroitâ€™s favor, even if a $32 million award would smash the previous high awarded in a room by more than $12 million, Skubal is the first American Leaguer to win consecutive Cy Young Awards since Pedro Martinez in 1999-2000.â€

That kind of resume changes how cases are viewed. Passan continued:

â€œAnd in a world where lesser pitchers get $30 million-plus a season and Skubal can compare his salary to any in MLB, his performance, the best pitcher in baseball â€” will be enough to carry the day.â€

In other words, precedent matters, but dominance matters more. Skubalâ€™s back-to-back Cy Youngs place him in a category that very few pitchers in modern history have ever occupied.

Even with logic, numbers, and awards on his side, Passan made it clear that nothing is guaranteed in the arbitration room.

â€œArbitration hearing rooms are notorious for their unpredictability,â€ Passan wrote. â€œLawyers who have argued cases have left the room convinced theyâ€™d made airtight arguments â€” and lost. Others were despondent in the aftermath, certain of defeat, and emerged victorious.â€

â€œWhich is to say that whatever approach Tarik Skubalâ€™s team takes in trying to convince a three-person panel that heâ€™s worthy of the $32 million heâ€™s seeking instead of the $19 million the Detroit Tigers are offering, the ultimate result is a crapshoot.â€

That uncertainty is what makes this case so fascinating â€” and potentially historic.

Beyond the legal drama, this standoff sends a message. Skubal is the face of the franchise, the best pitcher in baseball, and the foundation of Detroitâ€™s contention window. Filing at $19 million while he seeks $32 million creates a tension that goes far beyond one seasonâ€™s paycheck.

Whether the panel sides with Skubal or the Tigers, the outcome will ripple into future extension talks, trade rumors, and how the organization is viewed by its own superstar.

One way or another, Skubal will take the mound in 2026 as a Cy Young winner. The only question is whether heâ€™ll do it as the most highly paid arbitration player in MLB history.

The post MLB Insider Predicts Outcome for Tarik Skubal Arbitration Case With Detroit Tigers appeared first on Detroit Sports Nation.

title: Pirates' Paul Skenes can set all-time MLB record by breaking history of Dodgers legend
description: He's on an all-time great trajectory already.
fullText:
Pirates' Paul Skenes can set all-time MLB record by breaking history of Dodgers legend originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Paul Skenes is one of the best pitchers on the planet, and that really hasn't been questioned at any point during his first two MLB seasons with the Pittsburgh Pirates.

If he keeps this up, he'll have a chance to make all kinds of history and set all sorts of records.

In 2026, Skenes could set two records if he keeps up his current pace.

MLB.com's Sarah Langs wrote a new article this weekend breaking down the different all-time marks that could fall in the 2026 MLB season. Skenes featured prominently on the list.

MORE:Â Bo Bichette comments exhibit clear hyprocrisy

The first record that could be set is if Skenes leads the National League in ERA. It'd be the second consecutive year that he led in ERA.

Skenes would be the youngest to lead his league in ERA in back-to-back seasons since it was an official stat in 1913, according to Langs.

That previous record is currently held by Clayton Kershaw.

Skenes also could set a strikeout record.

"Skenes is also projected to lead the NL in strikeouts, with 237," Langs writes. "He would be the fifth youngest to lead his league in both ERA and strikeouts by age at the end of the season, older than only 1985 Gooden (20 years, 324 days), 1940 Bob Feller (21 years, 331 days), 1965 Sam McDowell (23 years, 12 days) and 2011 Kershaw (23 years, 193 days)."

MORE:Â The Reds aren't signing any free agents because of TV

The key to the Pirates' season ahead really isn't Skenes, though. They're expecting him to be a superstar, as usual.

Pittsburgh needs the rest of its roster to live up to Skenes. If Skenes can get some help, this can be a sneakily dangerous club.

title: A First Look at the Cardinalsâ€™ 2026 Season Through ZiPS
description: On Friday morning Dan Szymborski released the long-awaited Cardinals 2026 ZiPS projections and gave us all a short break from refreshing MLB Trade Rumors to see the latest on Brendan Donovan. ZiPS is the gold standard for publicly available projection systems and has been continuously refined to improve accuracy since Szymborski originally developed it in [â€¦]
fullText:
On Friday morning Dan Szymborski released the long-awaited Cardinals 2026 ZiPS projections and gave us all a short break from refreshing MLB Trade Rumors to see the latest on Brendan Donovan. ZiPS is the gold standard for publicly available projection systems and has been continuously refined to improve accuracy since Szymborski originally developed it in the early 2000s. If you havenâ€™t yet, make sure to check out the full set of projections.

The first sneak peek was originally tweeted out on Thursday.

A sneak peek at the ZiPS x @FanGraphs Depth Chart for the final ZiPS team, the St. Louis #Cardinals.#ZiPS26 pic.twitter.com/OsjW46VJPr

â€” Dan Szymborski (@DSzymborski) January 22, 2026

At first glance this looks better than expected! It is important to note that the graphic above is based on the ZiPS projected rate stats, but the playing time allocation is based on the FanGraphs Depth Chart page, so the WAR totals in the graphic are not meant to line up with the ZiPS projection tables in the article. This also means that we cannot just add up the WAR totals to get a projected win total. The team projections will come out closer to the start of the season and are based on millions of simulations that account for much more variability and nuance than midpoint projections. With that lengthy caveat out of the way, I do think it is still worthwhile to see how the teamâ€™s projections stack up with the projections going into last year as well as the actual results in 2025.

The Cardinals rotation was sneakily horrible last year thanks to the 250 innings given to Miles Mikolas and Erick Fedde, so even with the loss of Sonny Gray, the group as a whole wonâ€™t have to do much to improve.Â  Despite lacking a true standout, ZiPS sees enough depth to piece together a reasonable staff. While it may be deep, the rotation is also lacking upside. Dustin May is the only starting pitcher expected to open in the rotation with a projected strikeout rate over 20%. The Cardinals bullpen performed exceptionally well in 2025, so there is a lot of regression baked into the 2026 outlook. Getting a few breakout performances and/or starters moving to the pen and seeing their stuff play up will be a huge factor in the teamâ€™s 2026 storyline. Overall, I didnâ€™t see too many surprises in the projections, but a few that stood out to me were:

Hunter Dobbins is given a projection a little too close to Aaron Wilkerson for my liking. He will probably always be a pitch to contact guy, but he is going to need to strike out more than 15.8% of batters to make much of an impact.

Michael McGreevy projects as the staff ace as the only starting pitcher with an ERA+ greater than 100 and is given a 20% chance of putting up a 3+ WAR season.

JoJo Romero is projected for almost half the bullpen WAR at 0.9. Hopefully some general manager saw the ZiPS release and decided to increase the prospect value they are willing to offerâ€¦

On the position player side of things, you can see the hole at first base left by the Willson Contreras departure. The rest of the infield projects slightly better than last yearâ€™s projections and results. One thing to note here is that the Depth Charts page is only giving Wetherholt 371 plate appearances, so there is some upside there if he performs in line with his ZiPS projections and earns a full seasonâ€™s worth of plate appearances. The outfield was projected to be terrible going into last season and was able to meaningfully underperform even from that baseline. Nootbaar and Scott get solid projections in left and center field. Walker is projected for 518 plate appearances, which surely will not happen if he struggles as much as last year.

Looking a bit deeper at the individual player projections, Donovan, Nootbaar, Winn, and Burleson project about as expected. Winnâ€™s offense backing up a bit in 2025 hurt his outlook, but that is made up for by his improved defensive projection. His 80th percentile outcome of a 4.5 WAR season seems a little light given that he was on track to eclipse that for most of last year before fading late while dealing with the knee injury.

While the pitching projections didnâ€™t offer many surprises, there were a bunch of position player projections that jumped out to me.

JJ Wetherholt is projected for 2.9 WAR with a 100 OPS+ and above-average defense. While not flashy, this is an incredibly positive projection for a player with one full minor league season under his belt. ZiPS incorporates exit velocity data into the model, so it is good to see that Wetherholt was not knocked too much for his average performance on those metrics.

Ivan Herrera is projected for a 125 OPS+. Going into last season he was projected at 103, so it is good to see that the computer believes in his offensive breakout. The model does incorporate injury data, but I am assuming it is not aware of the saga around Herreraâ€™s arm problems and his impassioned pursuit of the starting catcher role. If he is able to catch 80-100 games, I think he would easily surpass his 80th percentile WAR projection of 3.5.

Jordan Walker maybe shouldnâ€™t be classified as a surprise, but you still hate to see a below replacement projection. The Cardinals still seem to believe in his upside and I am inclined to give them the benefit of the doubt as they try to sort through Walkerâ€™s issues.

Nolan Gorman projecting for 1.9 WAR and above-average defense was one of the biggest surprises for me. It will be interesting to see how much leeway he is given early in the year.

Jimmy Crooks is given a 2 WAR projection with an 89 OPS+. This was similar to the projection he received going into 2025. It is good to see that the computer still believes in him after a relatively lackluster AAA performance.

Nathan Church didnâ€™t convince the computer that his 2025 breakout was for real, as he still projects below average offensively and defensively.

Bryan Torres has a steadily growing fan club and can now count ZiPS among his admirers with a 105 OPS+. His -8 defensive rating hurts his overall value projection and will be something to keep an eye on if he breaks camp with the Cardinals.

Finally, a few prospects that donâ€™t project to open in St. Louis but that had encouraging projections were:

Joshua Baez getting a 94 OPS+ projection is super exciting. I was worried the computer would hold his high strikeout rate in the lower minors against him. He is projected for a 29% strikeout rate, so it is still a risky profile, but it also means there is more upside if he keeps the swing and miss in check as he moves up.

Deniel Ortiz was one of the breakout offensive prospects of the 2025 season. A projected OPS+ of 81 is incredibly solid for a player who has not yet reached Double-A. It is good to see ZiPS is not overly concerned with his high strikeout rate.

Leonardo Bernal continues to get love with a league average WAR projection. It is hard to see him getting much time this year, but he is still moving in the right direction.

All things considered, I am encouraged by where the projections landed. These arenâ€™t the Cardinals from the last several decades that pump out 88+ win projections, but they still have the underlying attribute of depth that made those teams successful. Szymborski himself mentioned that this looks like a .500 team, which would surpass most fansâ€™ expectations. I do think in all the talk of the rebuild, some fans are overlooking the importance of winning games in 2026. The Cardinals have a good farm system, but it is not the kind of system that can take a true-talent 70 win team and turn it into a World Series contender in a couple of years. If the 2026 team can meet or exceed the ZiPS expectations, the Cardinals will be primed for a competitive window moving forward.

title: Major League Baseball star detained by immigration officials prompting Nancy Pelosi to intervene
description: The 27-year-old Giants outfielder was stopped by Customs and Border Protection at Los Angeles International Airport Wednesday
fullText:
San Francisco Giants star Jung Hoo Lee was detained by immigration officials, prompting Representative Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat and former House Speaker, to intervene.

The 27-year-old Giants outfielder was stopped by Customs and Border Protection at Los Angeles International Airport Wednesday because he forgot documents in South Korea, Pelosiâ€™s office said in a statement shared by multiple news outlets.

"Our office is actively working with the Giants organization, our Congressional partners and federal liaisons to resolve this situation and secure Mr. Lee's release expeditiously," the two-time former House speaker said.

Lee was later released, the Giants said, after his â€œbrief travel issue at LAX due to a paperwork issue."

"The matter was quickly clarified with the appropriate authorities, and he has since been cleared to continue his travel. We appreciate the professionalism of all parties involved,â€ a spokesperson for the team told the media.

Leeâ€™s agent, Scott Boras, told the San Francisco Chronicle it was â€œnot anything political or anything like that.â€

Detentions by federal agents have become a hot-button issue amid President Donald Trumpâ€™s immigration crackdown.

Lee arrived at LAX ahead of an appearance at the Giantsâ€™ FanFest in San Ramon on Saturday. The tour, which has multiple stops across Northern California, gives fans a chance to meet players and coaches.

Lee is of South Korean descent, but he was born in Nagoya, Japan, where his father, Korean baseball star Jong Beom Lee, was playing for the Chunichi Dragons, according to his MLB profile. During his introductory press conference, Lee called himself â€œGrandson of the Wind.â€ His father is known as â€œSon of the Wind.â€

Lee made his debut in the majors in March 2024 after playing for the Kiwoom Heroes in Korea for seven years. Lee agreed to a six-year contract with the Giants worth $113 million in December 2023, ESPN reported, citing unnamed sources, at the time.

The Giants will begin spring training for the 2026 season in Scottsdale, Arizona, in early February.

title: Ranking the top 10 MLB teams entering 2026 Spring Training
description: Pitchers and catchers have their first workouts from February 9th to February 13th. This offseason saw many players move in the form of trades and free agency. As anticipation starts for the 2026 season, baseball fans are beginning to homeâ€¦
fullText:
Pitchers and catchers have their first workouts from February 9th to February 13th. This offseason saw many players move in the form of trades and free agency. As anticipation starts for the 2026 season, baseball fans are beginning to home in on their favorite teams.

Fans begin to research rosters, minor league prospects, and the 2026 schedules. Spring Training baseball brings hope to fans anxiously awaiting their favorite team to reach World Series glory. Here are the top 10 MLB teams heading into Spring Training.

Detroit rosters MLBâ€™s best starting pitcher in Tarik Skubal. The Tigers could trade their superstar if a long-term extension canâ€™t be reached. If Skubal is traded, the Tigers will be in need of a number one starting pitcher.

The teamâ€™s lineup features young players and blossoming superstar Riley Greene. This offseason, the front office helped strengthen Detroitâ€™s bullpen.

Last season, Houston missed the playoffs for the first time since 2016. The teamâ€™s shortcomings were due to injuries, most notably to Yordan Alvarez and team closer Josh Hader. This offseason, the Astros added free agent Japanese pitcher Tatsuya Imai.

Imai joins Hunter Brown and Christian Javier in Houstonâ€™s starting rotation. The key to Houstonâ€™s upcoming season is health.

On paper, teams are better than the Brewers, but the front office and coaching staff get the best out of the teamâ€™s roster. Last season, Milwaukeeâ€™s top starting pitching prospect, Jacob Misiorowski, made his debut and took the league by storm.

Misiorowski will join Freddie Peralta at the top of the teamâ€™s starting rotation. The Brewersâ€™ lineup will again be led by Christian Yelich, Brice Turang, and last seasonâ€™s breakout outfielder, Jackson Chourio.

Boston was led by ace starting pitcher Garrett Crochet in 2025. The starter had the best season of his career and will produce more production in 2026. The team lost third baseman Alex Bregman in free agency, but the lineup features Trevor Story, Jarren Duran, Wilyer Abreu, Roman Anthony, and newly acquired hitter Willson Contreras.

The Red Sox bolstered their rotation, signing starting pitcher Sonny Gray. If Boston can successfully slide prospect Marcelo Mayer into Bregmanâ€™s void, they can reach the playoffs again in 2026.

The Yankees have the lineup to win the World Series, but continue to fall short. Any team with Aaron Judge will always have the chance to win. The Yankees havenâ€™t made a splash in free agency, but the upcoming season will feature the return of starting pitcher Gerrit Cole.

Cole will rejoin the starting rotation that features Max Fried, Carlos Rodon, and breakout candidate Cam Schlitter. With Cody Bellinger locked up long-term, the glaring questions are whether shortstop Anthony Volpe can fix his consistency issues and if the pitching staff can stay healthy throughout the season.

Chicago started the first half of 2025 as one of MLBâ€™s best teams. However, the Cubs regressed mightily in the second half. This offseason, the team lost outfielder Kyle Tucker in free agency but signed Alex Bregman to fill the glaring hole at third base. The front office acquired starting pitcher Edward Cabrera, and he will join starting pitchers Shota Imanaga, James Taillon, Cade Horton, and Matthew Boyd.

Starting pitcher Justin Steele returns to the starting rotation after missing all of 2025 to elbow surgery. After outfielder Pete Crow-Armstrongâ€™s breakout season, the Cubsâ€™ lineup is projected to be one of the strongest in Major League Baseball.

Barring injuries, Seattleâ€™s rotation has the chance to be one of the leagueâ€™s best. Itâ€™s difficult to name a starting five better than the combination of Luis Castillo, Logan Gilbert, Bryan Woo, George Kirby, and Bryce Miller. The group makes up the best strength of the Marinersâ€™ roster.

They came up short during last seasonâ€™s playoff push but brings back a lineup that features Cal Raleigh, Josh Naylor, Randy Arozarena, and Julio Rodriguez. Seattle will be the team to beat in the AL West.

The Phillies are the best National League team to dethrone the Los Angeles Dodgers. Last season, Philadelphia fell to Los Angeles in the NLDS. Unfortunately, the team was without starting pitcher Zack Wheeler and is likely to begin 2026 without its ace. With Ranger Suarez leaving in free agency, the Phillies will look to Christopher Sanchez, Aaron Nola, and Jesus Luzardo as their top three starters.

Prospect Andrew Painter will have the opportunity to break Spring Training in the rotation, and he has one of the best arms of any minor league prospect. Philadelphiaâ€™s lineup returns veterans J.T. Realmuto, Bryce Harper, Trea Turner, Kyle Schwarber, and free agent acquisition Adolis Garcia. Outfielder Nick Castellanos is likely to be traded before Spring Training.

Toronto was one of MLBâ€™s top teams throughout the 2025 season. The Blue Jays represented the American League in the World Series but fell to the Dodgers in seven games. This season, Toronto looks to repeat as American League pennant winners. Its starting pitching rotation of Kevin Gausman, Dylan Cease, Shane Bieber, Jose Berrios, and postseason standout Trey Yesavage can be one of the top rotations in MLB.

They added to their lineup this season, adding Japanese free agent Kazuma Okamoto. The team hopes Okamoto will mitigate lost production following shortstop Bo Bichetteâ€™s signing with the Mets. The Japanese free agent will be included in a lineup that features Vladimir Guerrero Jr., Anthony Santander, Addison Barger, Daulton Varsho, and George Springer.

LA enters Spring Training as the top team in Major League Baseball. Their roster features Shohei Ohtani, the leagueâ€™s best player, and they added Kyle Tucker as a free agent.

Tucker joins the best lineup, top to bottom, and is positioned to have the best season of his career. If the starting rotation can stay healthy, the group of Yoshinobu Yamamoto, Tyler Glasnow, Blake Snell, Roki Sasaki, and Shohei Ohtani can finish as the leagueâ€™s top-ranked staff.

The front office brought in free agent closer Edwin Diaz to secure the ninth inning of ball games. For all the negative talk about the front officeâ€™s spending, one thing is clear: team ownership wants to win every season.

title: From one Hall of Famer to another, here is what Braves legend told Andruw Jones
description: Andruw Jones learned he will be elected to the 2026 MLB Hall of Fame, and wait until you hear what this Braves legend told Jones?
fullText:
From one Hall of Famer to another, here is what Braves legend told Andruw Jones originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

On Tuesday, long-time Braves center fielder Andruw Jones was announced as one of the players elected to the 2026 MLB Hall of Fame in his ninth year of the 10-year eligibility.

For any player to be elected, they must receive 75 percent of the ballot votes, and in Jones's first season, he received only 7 percent, which is a testament to his patience throughout the years.

The talent, of course, was never the issue for Jones, as the center fielder stood out for his impactful offensive and defensive abilities, which he brought to his 17-year career, 12 of which were spent with the Braves, and which greatly assisted the team during the runs in the late 90's arriving to the Major League, a season after the Braves won the 1995 World Series.

More:Â An Air Force Captain will pitch for Team USA at the World Baseball Classic

With the election, Jones joins his former teammates and manager, Greg Maddux, Tom Glavine, John Smoltz, Fred McGriff, Chipper Jones, and Bobby Cox in Cooperstown.

In fact, while Andruw was waiting patiently for his turn to reach the Hall of Fame, Chipper Jones encouraged him over the years, as the center fielder recalled, "Chipper said a long time ago, I don't think the Hall of Fame would be complete with Andruw being in it," Jones admitted.

Well, after Tuesday, the Hall of Fame will be completed by adding another Braves legend from those legendary squads.

The center fielder ended his career with 454 HR, 1,289 RBI, and a 24.4 WAR, to go along with his ten consecutive gold glove awards, making him one of the best outfielders in MLB history. Jones also made history, becoming the youngest player to ever homer in a World Series when the team faced off against the New York Yankees in 1996.

title: Chicago Cubs history unpacked, January 21
description: A Chicago Cubs-centric digest, with #Cubs, #MLB, and #MiLB content.
fullText:
On Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays,Â Bleed Cubbie BlueÂ is pleased to present aÂ Cubs-centric look at baseballâ€™s colorful past.Â Hereâ€™s a handy Cubs timeline, to help you follow the various narrative paths.

â€œMaybe I called it wrong, but itâ€™s official.â€ â€”Â Tom Connolly, HoF Umpire.

Happy Birthday to Mike Krukow*, farewell Hollywood Stars, and other storiesÂ for the discerning reader.

1921Â â€“ 1921Â â€“ JudgeÂ Kenesaw Mountain LandisÂ officially is signed asÂ baseball commissioner, to a seven-year, $350,000 contract. (1,2)

1936Â â€“ TheÂ Hollywood Stars, last-place finishers in theÂ Pacific Coast LeagueÂ inÂ 1935, move toÂ San Diego, where they will become theÂ Padres. The Stars were unable to pay the annual rent of $8,000 forÂ Wrigley Field. They will return inÂ 1938Â when theÂ San Francisco MissionsÂ move south to L.A. (2)

1947 â€“ A rule change that allowsÂ votingÂ only for players who were active afterÂ 1921Â produces four newÂ Hall of Fame members, breaking a logjam after years of theÂ BBWAAÂ electing hardly anyone: catcherÂ Mickey Cochrane, second basemanÂ Frankie Frisch, and pitchersÂ Lefty GroveÂ andÂ Carl Hubbell, all formerÂ Most Valuable PlayersÂ andÂ World SeriesÂ winners.Â Pie TraynorÂ misses selection by two votes. Hubbell was forbidden byÂ Ty CobbÂ to throw hisÂ screwballÂ inÂ Detroitâ€™sÂ farm system, but used it to win 253 games for theÂ New York Giants; Frisch went to the World Series eight times and batted .316 over 19 seasons; Grove won 300 games, and hisÂ battery-mate Cochrane retired with a .320 lifetimeÂ batting average, the highest of any catcher. (1,2)

1953Â â€“ TheÂ Baseball Writers Association of AmericaÂ passes overÂ Joe DiMaggioÂ in his first year of eligibility andÂ electsÂ pitcherÂ Dizzy DeanÂ and outfielderÂ Al SimmonsÂ to theÂ Hall of Fame. Dean gathers 209 votes while Simmonsâ€™ total of 199 is one more than needed. The colorful Dean had a .644 career winning percentage and won 120 games fromÂ 1932Â throughÂ 1936, including 30 wins inÂ 1934. Simmons, who drove in 100 runs in each of his first eleven major league seasons, was one of the most feared hitters of his time. Also joining DiMaggio, who finishes eighth in the voting, are in orderÂ Bill Terry,Â Bill Dickey,Â Rabbit Maranville,Â Dazzy Vance,Â Ted Lyons,Â Charles BenderÂ (ninth) andÂ Gabby HartnettÂ (tenth). All will eventually make it. DiMaggioâ€™s low total can be explained by the fact that there is no actual ballot, only write-in votes, and it is not clear whether DiMaggio is eligible since he played his last game only two years earlier. (1,2)

1993Â â€“Â Hall of FameÂ second basemanÂ Charlie GehringerÂ dies at the age of 89, one month after suffering a stroke. During a 19-year career with theÂ Detroit Tigers, Gehringer posted a .320Â batting averageÂ with 184Â home runsÂ and 1427Â RBI. InÂ 1937, he enjoyed arguably his finest season, leading theÂ American LeagueÂ with a .371 average. (2)

Cubs Birthdays: Mike Krukow*, Dave Smith, Alan Benes.

1522Â â€“ Head Inquisitor Adrian Florisz Boeyens is elected pope.

1793Â â€“ Louis XVIÂ of France is executed by guillotine in Paris, following his conviction for â€œhigh treasonâ€ by the newly created French Parliament (Convention nationale), during the French Revolution.

(1) â€”Â Today in Baseball History.

(3) â€”Â Society for American Baseball Research.

(5) â€”Â This Day in Chicago Cubs history.

Some of these items spread from site to site without being fact-checked, and that is why we ask for verifiable sources, in order to help correct the record.

title: Shaikin: Make starting pitchers great again? MLB isn't. This independent league will try
description: The United Shore Professional Baseball League (USPBL), an independent league based in Michigan, is recruiting players in order to "build the ability to pitch deep into games." Can it be done?
fullText:
The independent minor leagues are baseballâ€™s laboratories.

Pitch clocks? The robot umpires coming to the major leagues this year? The home run derby used to settle ties, as seen in last yearâ€™s All-Star Game? All first tested in an independent league.

Some concepts are hits. Some are flops.

The experiment to watch this year is almost spiritual in nature: Can professional baseball make starting pitching great again?

Baseballâ€™s obsession with velocity has dampened the soul of the sport. The marquee pitching matchup is an endangered species. The oohs and aahs over a 100-mph pitch have been replaced by yawns.

The potential solution, or at least a piece of one, is evident in this job description:

The United Shore Professional Baseball League (USPBL), an independent league based in Michigan, is recruiting for the position of â€œprimary starting pitcher.â€

The game isnâ€™t building traditional starters anymore. At the @uspbl, were changing that.

We are actively recruitingÂ Primary Starting PitchersÂ who want to take the ball every week, pitch deep into games, and become the durable, innings-capable arms MLB organizations need.

Thisâ€¦ pic.twitter.com/0JZvXEFsqW

â€” Justin Orenduff (@JustinOrenduff) December 1, 2025

The language is intentional. In todayâ€™s major leagues, a starting pitcher generally is selected, trained and deployed to throw as hard as he can for as long as he can. Five innings is perfectly acceptable, with a parade of harder-throwing reinforcements in the bullpen.

What the USPBL plans for a primary starting pitcher: â€œBuild the ability to pitch deep into games.â€

That used to be self-evident for a starting pitcher, but no longer. Yoshinobu Yamamoto turned into Sandy Koufax last October, with back-to-back complete games during the Dodgersâ€™ championship run.

However, in the regular season, the Dodgers did not throw a complete game, and neither did 12 other teams. The Dodgersâ€™ starters averaged 4.85 innings per game; no team averaged even six innings.

In 2025, three major league pitchers threw 200 innings. In 2010, 45 did.

â€œBeing able to get more Mark Buehrles or Cliff Lees back into the fold would be good for the game,â€ said Justin Orenduff, a 2004 Dodgers first-round draft pick and now the USPBL executive director of baseball strategy and development.

Buehrle, a five-time All-Star, and Lee, a four-time All-Star, each featured precision rather than power.

Lee, twice a Game 1 World Series starter, did not average 92 mph on his fastball but pitched 200 innings eight times. Buerhle, whose average fastball did not top 90 mph, pitched 200 innings for 14 consecutive years.

Neither might be drafted today. Major league teams crave velocity, and young pitchers train to boost it. The number of players throwing at least 95 mph at the Perfect Game national showcase increased sevenfold from 2014 to 2024, according to a report from Major League Baseball.

The average MLB fastball rose from 91 mph in 2008 to 94 mph in 2024, the report said.

â€œVelocity is the No. 1 predictor of success,â€ Billy Eppler, then the Angelsâ€™ general manager, told me in 2018.

Velocity also is associated with an increased risk of injury. Teams have implemented well-intentioned measures â€” pitch counts, innings limits, more rest between appearances â€” that have not mitigated the risks and might well have led to more injuries.

Kyle Boddy, the founder of Driveline, the seminal program for velocity training, said a hard-throwing pitcher is not going to manage his velocity on an inflexible pitch count.

â€œIf he goes 60 or 70 pitches, heâ€™s going to sit 100,â€ Boddy told Baseball America. â€œHeâ€™s not stupid. And if we tell him, â€˜Thereâ€™s no limits on you,â€™ but we keep taking him out after 70 pitches every time, heâ€™s going to realize whatâ€™s going on.

â€œIf he canâ€™t control the volume, the one lever he can control is the intensity. I personally think thatâ€™s worse for his arm, going max effort for shorter stints.â€

That ultimately works against developing starting pitchers capable of delivering six innings, the MLB report said.

â€œModern workload management strategies â€” ostensibly intended to prevent overuse, protect pitcher health, and maximize pitcher effectiveness â€” may actually increase injury risk by allowing and even incentivizing pitchers to throw with maximum effort on every pitch,â€ the report said, â€œrather than requiring pitchers to conserve energy and pace themselves in an effort to pitch through longer outings.â€

Not only does throwing harder increase the risk of injury, the MLB report said, but the resulting parade of strikeouts runs â€œcounter to contact-oriented approaches that create more balls in play and result in the type of on-field action that fans want to see.â€

In the independent Atlantic League, the league has run several years of testing on a â€œdouble hookâ€ rule: when a team removes its starting pitcher, it loses its designated hitter. That would incentivize a major league team to use its starter for six or seven innings instead of four or five, but it would not solve the underlying problem: What if the starting pitcher cannot work six or seven innings?

That is where Orenduff and the USPBL come in.

Every general manager says he would love a rotation of five 200-inning starters, if only he could find them. They cannot offer on-the-job training in the majors, lest their team find itself at a competitive disadvantage.

In an independent league, Orenduff need not worry about that. Tough matchup with the bases loaded in the fourth inning? Third time through the order in the sixth inning? Pitch through it.

â€œItâ€™s not going to be that quick pull,â€ he said.

This is not about leaving a starting pitcher out there to get crushed just to pitch through it. This is about shaking off the shackles of those one-size-fits-all limitations.

â€œYou basically want to start by showing fans and the industry, for example, that 100 pitches is just a number,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s completely arbitrary.

â€œSome guys may be able to go 110, 120. We want to be able to show that the game can still produce players that are successful on the mound, most importantly, but are capable of going beyond the fifth inning and beyond 100 pitches if the expectation and the leadership and the structure are there to support it.â€

The USPBL will have pretty much the same technology as major league teams do, to measure spin rates and recovery rates and every other rate. If you can maintain command and velocity, if you can get outs without max effort on every pitch, and if you can bounce back between innings and between starts, you may be able to be that primary starting pitcher.

Frankly, Orenduff says, all the velocity in the world cannot help your team if you cannot pitch.

â€œThat has to be a metric too: sustainability and availability,â€ he said.

He conducted a study evaluating each teamâ€™s top three pitching draft picks since 2013. With the caveats that some pitchers were traded and some prospects still are developing, Orenduff found that three in four of those top drafted pitchers never have pitched for the major league team that drafted them, at a combined cost to the 30 MLB teams of $800 million in signing bonuses.

â€œWe just have to have some sort of proof we can help more players have longer careers by being a little more flexible in how we frame things for them,â€ Orenduff said.

Hereâ€™s hoping the USPBL can discover some training methods that major league teams can use. Better that than listening to a major league manager with a 13-man pitching staff say after a game that he ran out of pitchers, as we too often hear. Can you imagine what Tommy Lasorda would have to say about that?

 Delivered at the start of each series.

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

fullText:

title: Mets Reportedly Still In On Cody Bellinger Despite Bo Bichette Deal
description: When the New York Mets signed Bo Bichette on Friday to a three-year, $126 million deal, many MLB fans (particularly those rooting for the New York Yankees) assumed that the Mets halt their pursuit of Cody Bellinger. Thatâ€™s not whatâ€™s happening, according to New York Mets On SIâ€™s Pat Ragazzo. â€œThe Mets are still in [â€¦]
fullText:
When the New York Mets signed Bo Bichette on Friday to a three-year, $126 million deal, many MLB fans (particularly those rooting for the New York Yankees) assumed that the Mets halt their pursuit of Cody Bellinger.

Thatâ€™s not whatâ€™s happening, according to New York Mets On SIâ€™s Pat Ragazzo.

â€œThe Mets are still in play for free agent first baseman/outfielder Cody Bellinger, as sources told Mets On SI on Friday,â€ Ragazzo wrote.

â€œThe versatile Bellinger fits the Mets at multiple positions given his above average defense at first base and in center and left field. Bellingerâ€™s left-handed bat would also provide added protection in the Metsâ€™ lineup for Francisco Lindor, Juan Soto and Bichette. Bellinger also has a .929 career OPS at Citi Field in 20 games.â€

â€œThe Mets could plug Bellinger in center or left field, or at first base if they arenâ€™t comfortable playing Jorge Polanco and Brett Baty at the position,â€ Ragazzo added.

Bellinger has carved out a dynamic nine-year MLB career marked by peaks and valleys. Debuting with the Los Angeles Dodgers in 2017, he earned Rookie of the Year honors with 39 home runs. His 2019 MVP season saw him smash 47 homers while batting .305, followed by a 2020 World Series title. Injuries hampered him in 2021-22, leading to a non-tender and a rebound with the Chicago Cubs in 2023 (.307 average, 26 homers). In 2024, he hit .266 with 18 long balls before opting out of his deal.

Bellingerâ€™s 2025 campaign with the Yankees represented a strong resurgence, batting .272 with 29 home runs, 98 RBIs, and 13 stolen bases in 152 games. He posted an .813 OPS, 125 wRC+, and delivered memorable moments like a three-homer game against the Cubs, aiding the Yankeesâ€™ playoff push.

Bellinger remains a free agent, with ongoing talks stalled over contract length (he seeks seven years, while New York offers five at $155-160 million).

title: Mariners make a 1-for-1 pitcher trade with the Reds
description: Seattle is adding to its MLB roster.
fullText:
Mariners make a 1-for-1 pitcher trade with the Reds originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Seattle Mariners clearly felt their MLB bullpen could use an upgrade.

On Thursday, they made a trade with the Cincinnati Reds trading away a pitching prospect for a major league arm.

The Mariners announced the deal Thursday evening.

Coming to Seattle: right-handed pitcher Yosver Zulueta.

The Reds are getting righty Dusty Revis.

The Mariners had to designate infielder Samad Taylor for assignment to clear space on the 40-man roster.

Zulueta is 27 years old and has made 19 MLB appearances over the past two seasons.

His ERA in those stints is 5.32, and he has 25 strikeouts in 23.2 innings pitching.

MORE:Â An Air Force Captain will pitch for Team USA at the World Baseball Classic

Zulueta is 6-foot-1 and averages 96.3 miles per hour on his fastball. He's originally from Cuba and first signed with the Blue Jays in 2019.

The player the Mariners traded to the Reds, Revis, is a 22-year old right-hander who was an 11th-round pick in the 2025 MLB Draft out of Western Carolina. Revis has yet to make his professional pitching debut.

The Mariners had to expose Taylor to waivers to make room for Zulueta. He's a versatile defender who could draw interest. In 2025 in Triple-A, Taylor hit .296 with 124 runs scored, 27 doubles, seven triples, 17 homers, 86 RBI, 44 steals and 73 walks.

title: Ex-Padres co-owner Fowler to take Lincoln controlling stake
description: Former executive chairman and co-owner of Major League Baseball side San Diego Padres, Ron Fowler, is set to take a controlling stake in English third-tier side Lincoln City.
fullText:
A former executive chairman and co-owner of Major League Baseball team the San Diego Padres is set to take a controlling stake in League One club Lincoln City.

American Ron Fowler initially bought a minority interest in third-tier Lincoln in April 2024, and he is now poised to replace Arizona-based Harvey Jabara as the majority shareholder if his bid is cleared by the English Football League.

Lincoln's board approved a proposal from Fowler to increase his stake - through his company Liquid Investments - to more than 25% on 11 December.

Fowler, whose son Andrew is also involved in the club, will take on the position of chairman at LNER Stadium and will "assume responsibility for the funding of the club for the immediate future".

The ownership shake-up at Lincoln, who are second in the table, was confirmed as a "future development" in the club's annual accounts covering the 12 months up to June 2025.

"Acquiring 25% or more of the share capital is regarded by the EFL as acquiring control and consequently Liquid Investments Inc will need to demonstrate they are eligible to acquire control and are able to and will provide the necessary funding to ensure the club can continue to operate post-acquisition," the club noted in its report.

Fowler will take on responsibility for a promotion-chasing side that has reported a loss of just under Â£2.9m relating to the 2024-25 season.

While the club's turnover was a record Â£8.5m, up from just under Â£7m the previous season, their losses were down from just under Â£3m a year earlier.

It was also a season in which the club's shareholders put Â£3.6m into the club.

Funding that Fowler now intends to put into the club going forward is said to have already been "earmarked" for "various projects at the LNER Stadium".
